page.lettertext:
fol.109r
May it please yo
r
good L. to be advertised, that I
sent yo
w
the 7 of this moneth, the long expected
Answear of
e
General states
: w
ch
I finde to be
Negative to all her
Ma
ties
demaundes: not only
those whereto they are not tied by vertue of
e
Treaty, but to every mater els, wherunto they are
bound by expresse conditions. To proceede ther-
upon by way of Replie, and to specifie
e wronges,
that they offer to her Ma
tie
I knowe to yo
r
L. it
is more then needeth, and to them it is in vaine,
being bent to persist in their obstinat course. For
if it
be
possible, that ether by mine owne experience,
or by others informac
o
n, I should knowe the dispo-
sition and humo
r
of this people, having stoode so
stiffely so long in a wilfull denial of all
at is re-
quired, I thinke they will rather hazard the state
of their contrey, then be drawen against their willes
to alter their purpose. In w
ch
respect, and lest my
further dealing should turne her Ma
tie
to prejudice,
I have resolved to be silent, and to attend from
yo
r
L. w
at
her Hig
nes
will command.
We have certaine advertisment, that there are al-
ready Ambassado
rs
deputed from
e
Empero
r
, to pro-
pose a generall peace, to
e states of these Provinces.
It hath bin thought upon heere, w
at
were fittest to be
done, to prevent
e inconvenience
at may growe
upon their comming. For though they stand not in
doubt of
e peoples inclinac
o
n to any suche motion,
yet they hold it best to be assured, and not to
put it to
e choise of their inconstant disposition.
Againe they are afraide, as I am secretly infor-
med, that suche conditions of peace may be offered
unto them as being knowen unto her Ma
tie
may
make her desirous to enter into Treaty. For preventi
o
fol.109v
wherof and of all inconveniences, they have resol-
ved to send expressely to
e Empero
r
, and to desire
him to forbeare from sending unto them: for that
the mater of peace hath bin often debated, and they
finde no securitie in any conditions,
at
e King can
propose. they will also write to
e
Duke of Saxonie
,
e
Elector Palatin
,
e
Marquis of Brandebourgh
,
e
D. of Brunswicke
,
e
Lantgrave of Hesse
, and
to
e
bishop of Witzbourgh
, whose brother is said to
be one of
e Ambassado
rs
, to intreat them very
earnestly, not to give any eare to
e fraudulent
offers of
e Spaniard, but to proceede to their late
determination, for cleering
e Rhine from forraine
garrisons. All
e doubt that is conceaved is,
at
the Ambassadors will be heere, before their letters
can come to
e Empero
rs
handes. It is some
mens opinion, that to lette them come, but not
remaine, and to answear to their motion w
t
a
flatte refusall, were a better course then
e other,
and not so subject to offense. Howbeit they are
minded, to write as I have signified.
We are heere in good hope, that
e mutinies begonn
in the Enemies garrisons of
Diest
and
Herentals
,
in
e contrey of
Brabant
, who demaund, as is re-
ported for 50 monethes pay, will extend to other
places. For it is said undoubtedly, that in
e Ene-
mies campe, there are many discontentments, not
for mony maters only, but for sundrie occasions,
w
ch
are greater among
e greatest, then those of
meaner qualitie. It is also given fourth, that
e King of Spaine, doth take unto himself the
bestowing of suche goverments and offices of charge,
as were accustomed before to be given by
e
Duke
fol.110r
of Parma
. Whiche will multiplie, men thinke,
e
mater of dislike,
at is kindled already.
We have also letters from
Andwerp
, that in
e late
assembly of
e states of those Provinces,
e Dukes
demaundes for contribution have bin flatly rejected.
There is no opinion
at this Winter there
will be any great mater attempted by him. For
his martial people are not freed of those mortal
diseases, wherw
t
they were infected at their being
in
Fraunce
. For whiche he hath dispersed them
abroad, in
e land of
Liege
, and other places of
rest. Nevertheles we have intelligence at this p
n
t,
that to
e nomber of 1200 have entred
e contrey
about
Utrecht
, and done some smalle spoile upon
the boores, but retired again w
t
in Lesse then 3
houres. I have sent yo
r
L. heerewith
the copies of certaine letters, whiche were lately in-
ercepted by
e souldiers of
Berghen
, and being
written in Cipher were lately deciphred by
Mons
r
de S
t
Aldegonde
. The contents of
e letters
import not muche,
yet
because in some pointes
e Ene-
mies estates is discovered by them, I thought yo
r
L.
would willingly give them
e reading. The ori-
ginal letters were in Spanishe, but I have sent
them unto yo
w
translated into Frenche. And
because I do presume, that it might be beneficiall
to
e Citie of
Geneva
, to see w
at
was written, I have
sent other copies unto them. The vicount
of
Turen
, who arrived at
e
Hage
e 17 of this
moneth, hath bin in
e assembly of
e General states,
hath shewed them
e cause of his going into
Germany
,
and required their helpe, for
e intended Levies.
All his speeches of her Ma
tie
were full of gratitude
and hono
r
, in respect of her succo
rs
given to the Kinge
fol.110v
29 De
c
90
whiche he declared at some length, and in very
good termes. Howbeit, he had no answear from
the states, but in general wordes, That they would
deliberat upon his demaunde, and recommend it
effectually to
e Provinces, and about
e beginning of
the next moneth deliver their resolution unto
M
r
Busenval
. By that that I can conjecture, by
privat c
o
ference w
t
my frindes, they will straine
their estate, to advaunce
e action to
e uttermost.
Also the Vicount hath dealt w
t
me in particular
to yeld w
at
furtherance I shall be able: to w
ch
effect he did suppose, that I had bin charged by
her Ma
tie
whiche I am not as yet. though I
doubt not therein of her Hig
nes
pleasure, and in
that regard have signified, that my best ende-
vo
r
shall not want. Of all other maters
at
may concern those affaires,
S
r
Horace Palla-
vicinie
will advertise yo
r
L.
for w
ch
I take
my humble leave. From
e Hage. De
c
29
1590
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden
Tho. Bodley
